chunks.original_text: 神人答曰：故肝神去，出游不时还，目无明也。 心神去不在，其唇青白也。 肺神去不在，其鼻不通也。 肾神去不在，其耳聋也。 脾神去不在，令人口不知甘也。 头神去不在，令人眴冥也。 腹神去不在，令人腹中央甚不调，无所能化也。 四肢神去，令人不能自移也。 夫神精其性常居空闲之处，不居污浊之处也。 欲思还神，皆当斋戒，悬象香室中，百病消亡，不斋不戒，精神不肯还反人也，皆上天共诉人也。 所以人病积多，死者不绝。 《太平经第四十五卷》又云：今天不恶人有庐室也，乃恶人穿凿地太深，皆为创伤，或得地骨，或得地血者。 泉是地之血也，石为地之骨也。 地是人之母，妄凿其母，母既病愁苦，所以人固多病不寿也。 凡凿地动土，入地不过三尺。 为法一尺者，阳所照气，属天也。 二尺者，物所生气，属中和也。 三尺者，及地身气，属阴。 过此而下者，伤地形皆为凶也。 古者，依山谷岩穴不兴梁柱，所以其人少病也。 后世贼土过多，故多病也。 又云：有问者曰：今时有近流水而居，不凿井，何故多病不寿，何也？ 答曰：如此者，是明天地既怒及其北伍，更相承负，比如一家有过，及其兄弟也。 是知穿地皆下得水，水乃地之血脉，宁不病乎？ 又云：有问者曰：今人或有不动土，有所立便，旦时有就，故舍自若有凶，何也？ 答曰：如是者，行动不利，犯神凶也。 问曰：犯何神也？ 答曰：神者非一，不可务名也。 又云：有问者曰：今有起土，反吉无病害者，何也？ 答曰：皆有害，但得良善地者不即病害人也，久久会且害人也。 若得恶地，即病害人也。 故大起土有大凶恶，小起土有小凶恶，是即地忿，使神灵以此之灾多病人也。 又云：有问者曰：今河海下田作室庐，或无柱梁，入地未三尺，辄得水，复当云何也？ 答曰：此同为害也。 宜复浅之者，地之薄皮也，近地经脉也，若人有厚皮，难得血血出，亦为伤也。 薄皮者易得血，血出亦为伤也。 夫伤人者，不复道其皮厚与薄也。 见血为罪也。 人不欲见伤，伤之则怒地，何独欲乐见伤之哉！ 夫天地乃人之真本，阴阳之父母也，而子何从当得伤其父母乎？ 又云：有问者曰：今子当得饮食於母，故人穿井而饮之，有何过乎？ 答曰：不尔，今人饮其母乃就其出泉之处也。 故人乳者，人之泉也，若地有水泉也，可饮人也。 今岂可无故穿凿母皮肤而饮其血汁耶？ 《太真科上》云：笃病救命名为义斋，三日夜高德一人为斋主，五人为从官，精诚好乐，箓生亦可从斋，非好乐，进德不得，从斋也。 又云：救解父母师君同道大灾病厄斋官露坛大谢阑格散发泥额礼三十二天，斋中奏子午章，苦到必感，依旨教涂炭斋法也。 斋悉门中，然七灯祖延，光明又五灯井灶门阁各一致，聪明福也。 又云：法师宣法，众官精苦行礼，得节仪序，不亏病人，受恩渐蒙差愈，三日斋心，克有效者，赐师算三十，从官小算二十斋日计，倍为率也。 三洞珠囊卷之一竟 三洞珠囊卷之二
chunks.translated_text:
The Perfected One answered: “When the spirit of the liver departs and does not return in due time, the eyes lose their brightness. When the spirit of the heart departs, the lips turn pale. When the spirit of the lungs departs, the nose becomes blocked. When the spirit of the kidneys departs, the ears grow deaf. When the spirit of the spleen departs, the mouth cannot taste sweetness. When the spirit of the head departs, one becomes dizzy and disoriented. When the spirit of the abdomen departs, the center of the belly falls into great disorder, and nothing can be transformed. When the spirits of the four limbs depart, one cannot move on one’s own. The nature of the spirit and essence is to dwell in quiet and secluded places, not in defiled and turbid ones. If one wishes to recall the spirits, one must fast and maintain purity, hang their images in a fragrant chamber, and all illnesses will vanish. Without fasting and purity, the spirits will not return to the person, and all will ascend to heaven to accuse them. Thus, people’s illnesses accumulate, and the dead do not cease.”

*Scroll Forty-Five of the Scripture of Great Peace* further states: “Heaven does not resent people having dwellings, but resents them digging too deeply into the earth, causing wounds. Some obtain the earth’s bones, some its blood. Springs are the earth’s blood, and stones are its bones. The earth is humanity’s mother; recklessly piercing one’s mother causes her to suffer grief and pain, so people are often sick and short-lived. When digging into the earth, one should not go deeper than three feet. The first foot belongs to the yang qi, which is of heaven. The second foot belongs to the qi of living things, which is of harmony. The third foot reaches the earth’s own qi, which is of yin. Beyond this lies injury to the earth’s form, and all is inauspicious. In ancient times, people relied on mountain valleys and caves, not erecting beams and pillars, so they fell ill less often. Later generations excessively harmed the earth, so they suffer more illnesses.”

It is further asked: “Nowadays, some live near flowing water and do not dig wells, yet they still fall ill and die young. Why is this?” The answer: “This is because heaven and earth are already angered by their northern neighbors, who bear the burden of one another’s faults, like a family where one member’s transgression affects their siblings. Thus, digging into the earth to obtain water—water being the earth’s blood vessels—how could one not fall ill?”

It is further asked: “Some people do not disturb the earth, yet when they build a dwelling, misfortune befalls them at once. Why is this?” The answer: “Such people act at inauspicious times, offending the spirits and inviting misfortune.” Asked, “Which spirits do they offend?” The answer: “Spirits are not one but many; one need not seek their names.”

It is further asked: “Some dig into the earth yet encounter good fortune and no illness. Why is this?” The answer: “There is always harm, but if one obtains good earth, the harm does not manifest immediately. Over time, it will still afflict people. If one obtains bad earth, illness strikes at once. Thus, great earthworks bring great misfortune, and small ones bring minor misfortune—this is the earth’s wrath, causing spirits to inflict these disasters and make people ill.”

It is further asked: “Now, when building dwellings in low-lying fields near rivers and seas, where no pillars or beams are needed, and water is found before digging three feet deep, what should be done?” The answer: “This is equally harmful. One should dig even shallower, for this is the earth’s thin skin, near its meridians. Just as a person with thick skin makes it hard to draw blood, which is still an injury, so too with thin skin: blood comes easily, but it is still an injury. The harm lies not in whether the skin is thick or thin, but in seeing blood, which is a transgression. People do not wish to be injured, so why would they wish to injure the earth and provoke its anger? Heaven and earth are humanity’s true origin, the father and mother of yin and yang. How can a child rightfully injure their parents?”

It is further asked: “Now, children receive sustenance from their mother, so people dig wells to drink. What fault is there in this?” The answer: “It is not so. People drink from their mother at the place where springs emerge. A mother’s milk is a person’s spring; just as the earth has water springs, one may drink from them. But how can one recklessly pierce their mother’s skin and drink her blood and fluids?”

*The Upper Scroll of the Perfect Writs* states: “For those gravely ill, the rescue rite is called the Rite of Righteous Fasting. For three days and nights, a person of high virtue serves as the fasting master, with five as attendants. Sincerity and joy are essential; those who have received the registers may also participate. Without joy and moral progress, one may not join the fast. Further, to rescue and release parents, teachers, lords, or fellow Daoists from great disasters and calamities, the fasting officials perform the Great Expiation Rite at an open-air altar, scattering their hair, smearing their foreheads with mud, and paying homage to the Thirty-Two Heavens. During the fast, they recite the *Zi-Wu Chapters* at midnight and noon. If their suffering is sincere, they will surely be moved. This follows the method of the *Fasting Rite of Liquid and Ashes*. Within the fasting hall, they light seven ancestral lamps to extend blessings, and five more lamps—one each at the well, stove, gate, and pavilion—to bring wisdom and fortune. Further, when the Dharma Master expounds the teachings, the assembled officials perform the rites with utmost sincerity, adhering to the proper order. If they do not fail the sick, the recipients will gradually recover. After three days of fasting, if there is evident efficacy, the master is granted thirty years of lifespan, and the attendants twenty, calculated by doubling the days of the fast.”

*Scroll One of the Pearl Satchel of the Three Caverns* concludes.
*Scroll Two of the Pearl Satchel of the Three Caverns* begins.

chunks.original_text: 大唐陆海羽客王悬河修 贫俭品 《道学传第四》云：范豺者，巴西阆中人也，或作侪字。 容止都雅，不言先见，不说机祥，闲恬无欲，终日默然，结络败布以绳为网，披苦才得蔽形，冬夏徒跣脚不皴裂，四时无寝，□音肌若处子，美姿颜，应接恒笑，众咸敬而安之。 又以宋太元十四年到荆州，居于南郡枝江县之富城洲尾巴芒中，亦有屋宇，不障风霜，以桑柴为床，束稿插其间，有一空箪。 一瓦瓶，装担枕倚以卧，或有十日荷担乞食，口绝粳梁醪醴滋味果实，唯粗粟饭菜羹，食一升许便过旬日也。 行甚驶，语甚急，自非精意听受，略不可解。 恒小坐恭敬，不以高卑易心，不与俗中荣贵人语，恒闭眼不听声乐，恒卧而独语。 人问之，辄云王建武来。 俄又作，余端应对，不可寻检也。 又云：生资一毫悉无，箪瓶悉空也。 又云：遥视其衣服杂色，败布帽，又数十年故物，殊觉不净， 既至甚香洁也。 第五卷又云：刘凝之，字志安，小名长年，南郡枝江人也。 王公赠遗，一无所受，家财事业，悉分与弟侄，出於蒿莱之中，而为环堵之室，非力作不取也。 夫妻齐操，能以苦节自安，不拘小节，常与妻共取荚车入市门，随物贵贱而卖之，周食余便以乞人，虽复荒年绝粒，不革其操。 妻梁州刺史郭诠女，遣送丰华，凝之悉分赡亲属，以尽为限，妇亦无吝心也。 又云：性好山水，乃携妻子跨崖越岭为小蓬室，妻子皆从不知所终也。 第十卷云：东乡宗超，字逸伦，高密黔陬人也。 梁庐陵威王为起造房宇廊庑，莫不华壮，供养法具，咸悉精奇，唯先生所居茅茨不改，衣服床帷务存简率，常坐一圆枯蘖，移遂有膝痕，卉冠莞席穿缺不换也。 又云：严寄之，字静处，丹阳句容人也。 舍家入道，菜食布衣，体无寸帛也。 第十一卷云：张泽，字士和，吴郡吴人也。 专心道法，沈浮世也，随时语默，居贫守约，处之无闷也。 第十三卷云：庾承仙，字祟光，颖川鄢陵人也。 明老庄，至行清俭，布衣莞席，长斋蔬食四十余年，恒以讲说为务也。 又云：孟道养，字孝元，外名援，平昌人也。 为性慈仁，布衣周身，蔬食充口，此外萧然，执行精勤，未尝殆倦，行道礼拜，不避寒暑也。 第十五卷云：戴胜，字世荣，晋陵曲阿人也。 少而出家，贫尽尝为乡人刘表署作。 表是将士，好田猎，胜乃弃\之入茅山也。 第十六卷云：孔灵产，字灵产，会稽山阴人也。 遭母忧，燕酌珍羞自此而绝，饘蔬布素，志毕终身也。 第十八卷云：邓郁之，字玄达，南阳新野人也。 隐南岳，行则独往，居无常室，寒暑唯着弊衲，丧不结发，发长则剪之，齐永明时人也。 《列仙传上》云：幼伯子者，冬常着单衣，盛暑着檽桍，形貌岁岁异，后数十年更壮，时人莫知也。 ＇ 《神仙传第四》云：孔元者，许昌人也。 常服茯苓、松实，恶衣蔬食也。 焦先，字孝然，河东太阳人也。 年百七十岁，常食白石，结草为庵於山边。 衣败卖薪於市，买故衣着。 冬常单衣，颜色赫然，休息常如暑夏饮酒之状也。 韬光品 《大洞经下》云：太上大道君，形沈八玄，韬光万源，浩浩冥贯，条条霞标，神秀外觉，气弥炎洲，容与大化，寥寥本无，太空任奇，即色随消。 《道学传第五》云：东方朔，字曼蒨，平原厌次人也。

**On Frugality and Austerity**
*From the "Biographies of Daoist Scholars, Scroll Four" in the* Pearl Satchel of the Three Caverns, *compiled by the Tang dynasty’s Master of the Vast Sea of Dao, Wang Xuanhe*

It is said: Fan Chai, a native of Langzhong in Baxi (or written as *Chai*), possessed an elegant and refined demeanor. He never spoke of omens or portents, remaining serene and desireless, silent throughout the day. He wove tattered cloth into a net with rope, wearing coarse garments just sufficient to cover his body. Winter or summer, he went barefoot, yet his skin never cracked. He slept little in all seasons, his flesh as smooth as a maiden’s, his countenance fair. When engaging others, he always smiled, and all who knew him respected and found peace in his presence.

In the fourteenth year of the Taiyuan reign of the Liu Song dynasty, he arrived in Jingzhou and dwelled at the tail of Fucheng Isle in Zhijiang County, Nanjun, amidst the reeds. Though he had a hut, it offered no shelter from wind or frost. His bed was made of mulberry branches, stuffed with straw, and beside it stood an empty bamboo basket and a clay jar. He carried these on a pole, resting his head upon them to sleep. Sometimes he would beg for food for ten days at a time, never tasting fine grains, wine, or delicacies—only coarse millet, vegetables, and broth. A single *sheng* of food would sustain him for over ten days. He walked swiftly and spoke rapidly; unless one listened with utmost attention, his words were nearly unintelligible. He often sat in quiet reverence, his demeanor unchanged whether before high or low. He never spoke to worldly nobles or honored men, kept his eyes closed to avoid hearing music, and often lay murmuring to himself. When asked, he would say, "King Jianwu has come." Moments later, he would resume, answering other questions in ways that defied comprehension.

It is also said: He owned not a single possession, his basket and jar always empty. From afar, his patched and multicolored robes, tattered hat, and decades-old garments appeared unclean, yet upon closer inspection, they were strangely fragrant and immaculate.

*Scroll Five* further records: Liu Ningzhi, styled Zhi’an and nicknamed Changnian, was a native of Zhijiang in Nanjun. He refused all gifts from nobles and officials, dividing his family’s wealth and property among his younger brothers and nephews. Emerging from the wilderness, he built a humble abode with his own hands, taking nothing he had not earned. He and his wife lived in shared austerity, finding contentment in hardship. Unconcerned with trivial matters, they would push a cart of beans into the marketplace, selling at whatever price the day offered. Whatever food remained after their needs, they gave to the poor. Even in famine, when they themselves went without grain, they never abandoned their principles.

His wife was the daughter of Guo Quan, the Prefect of Liangzhou, who had sent her off with lavish dowry. Ningzhi distributed it all among their relatives, giving until nothing remained, and his wife bore no resentment.

It is also said: Fond of mountains and rivers, he took his wife and children to cross cliffs and ridges, building a small thatched hut. His family followed, and none knew where they ultimately settled.

*Scroll Ten* records: Zong Chao of Dongxiang, styled Yilun, was a native of Qianzou in Gaomi. When the Prince of Luling of the Liang dynasty built him halls and corridors, all were grand and resplendent, with ritual implements of exquisite craftsmanship. Yet the master’s own dwelling remained a thatched hut, unchanged. His clothing, bedding, and curtains were all simple and unadorned. He often sat upon a round, withered stump, its surface worn smooth by his knees. His straw hat and woven mat were threadbare and broken, yet he never replaced them.

It is also said: Yan Jizhi, styled Jingchu, was a native of Jurong in Danyang. He left his family to follow the Dao, eating only vegetables and wearing plain cloth, his body never covered by even an inch of silk.

*Scroll Eleven* records: Zhang Ze, styled Shi’he, was a native of Wu in Wu Commandery. Devoted to the Dao and its teachings, he drifted through the world, speaking or remaining silent as circumstances demanded. Though poor, he lived within his means, never troubled by his condition.

*Scroll Thirteen* records: Yu Chengxian, styled Chongguang, was a native of Yanling in Yingchuan. Well-versed in the *Laozi* and *Zhuangzi*, he lived with purity and frugality, wearing plain cloth and a woven mat. For over forty years, he maintained a vegetarian fast, devoting himself to teaching and expounding the Dao.

It is also said: Meng Daoyang, styled Xiaoyuan and also known as Yuan, was a native of Pingchang. Naturally kind and benevolent, he clothed himself in plain garments and ate only vegetables, owning nothing beyond the essentials. Diligent in his practice, he never grew weary, performing rituals and prostrations regardless of cold or heat.

*Scroll Fifteen* records: Dai Sheng, styled Shirong, was a native of Qu’e in Jinling. He left home in his youth and, though impoverished, once worked under Liu Biao, a local official fond of hunting. Sheng abandoned this life to enter Maoshan.

*Scroll Sixteen* records: Kong Lingchan, styled Lingchan, was a native of Shanyin in Kuaiji. After his mother’s death, he renounced wine, meat, and delicacies, living on gruel, vegetables, and plain cloth for the rest of his life.

*Scroll Eighteen* records: Deng Yuzhi, styled Xuanda, was a native of Xinye in Nanyang. He withdrew to Mount Nanyue, traveling alone and dwelling in no fixed abode. In cold and heat, he wore only tattered robes, never tying his hair after mourning. When his hair grew long, he cut it. He lived during the Yongming era.

The *Biographies of Immortals, Scroll One* states: You Bozi wore only a single garment in winter and a coarse coat in summer. His appearance changed year by year, and after decades, he appeared younger. No one could fathom his age.

The *Biographies of Divine Immortals, Scroll Four* states: Kong Yuan of Xuchang subsisted on *fuling* and pine nuts, wearing coarse clothes and eating simple fare.

Jiao Xian, styled Xiaoran, was a native of Taiyang in Hedong. At 170 years old, he ate white stones and built a thatched hut by the mountainside. His clothes were tattered, so he sold firewood in the market to buy old garments. In winter, he wore only a single layer, his complexion ruddy, resting as if in the heat of summer after drinking wine.

**On Concealing Radiance**
From the *Lower Scripture of the Great Cavern*:
The Supreme Lord of the Great Dao, his form submerged in the Eight Mysteries, his radiance concealed within the Ten Thousand Sources. Vast and boundless, he pervades the unseen, his branches marked by rosy clouds. His divine splendor stirs outwardly, his *qi* suffuses the flaming isles. In harmony with the great transformation, he dwells in the primordial void. The vast emptiness embraces the strange, and form dissolves with the transient.

*Biographies of Daoist Scholars, Scroll Five* records: Dongfang Shuo, styled Manqian, was a native of Yanci in Pingyuan.

chunks.original_text: 洁其道而秽其迹，清其质而浊其文。 若乃远心广度，宏才丽辩，惆傥博物，触类多能也。 又严君平者，名遵，蜀郡人也。 非其服弗服，非其食弗食。 常卖卜成都市，日得百钱，足以自养则闭肆门，下帘修道，沈深不作苟见，不治苟德，久幽而不改其操，未尝仕，年九十余终于家。 第六卷云：诸慧开，字智远，吴兴乌程人也。 性处幽静，常习闲寂，精思内修，每绝游往，或问何能幽悒如此，答曰：论动则六合未旷，语静则环堵有余。 第八卷云：陶弘景，字通明，魏郡平阳人也。 明帝时，栖憩钟岭，隐居更造楼，深自潜匿也。 第十三卷云：庾承仙，字崇光，颖川人也。 再征为本州主簿，不出。 又遣就拜，乃闭门幽遁，使者不得前也。 勑追召道士品 《道学传第七》云：陆修静，字元德，吴兴东迁人也，隐庐山瀑布山修道。 宋明帝思弘道教，广求名德，悦先生之风，遣招引。 太始三年三月乃诏江州刺史王景宗以礼敦劝，发遣下都。 先生辞之以疾，频奉诏。 帝未能致，弥增钦伫，中使相望，其在必至。

Purity in the Dao yet concealment in its traces, clarity in essence yet obscurity in its manifestations. As for those of far-reaching mind and expansive capacity, of vast talent and brilliant eloquence, of untrammeled erudition and mastery across all fields—such was his nature.

There was also Yan Junping, whose given name was Zun, a native of Shu Commandery. He would wear no garment not befitting the Way, consume no food not in accord with it. He often practiced divination in the market of Chengdu, earning a hundred coins daily—enough for his sustenance—whereupon he would close his shop, lower the curtain, and cultivate the Dao. Profound and unwavering, he never made frivolous displays nor pursued superficial virtue. Though long secluded, he never altered his resolve, never served in office, and passed away at home in his nineties.

**Scroll Six** records: Zhu Huikai, styled Zhiyuan, was a native of Wucheng in Wu Commandery. By nature, he dwelt in seclusion, ever practicing tranquility and inner refinement. He often cut off all travel and social visits. When asked how he could remain so reclusive, he replied: *"To speak of activity is to find even the Six Directions insufficient; to speak of stillness is to find even a single room more than enough."*

**Scroll Eight** records: Tao Hongjing, styled Tongming, was a native of Pingyang in Wei Commandery. During the Ming Emperor’s reign, he retired to Mount Zhong, where he built a hermitage and concealed himself in deep seclusion.

**Scroll Thirteen** records: Yu Chengxian, styled Chongguang, was a native of Yingchuan. Twice summoned to serve as Registrar of his home province, he refused. When envoys were sent to formally appoint him, he shut his door and withdrew into seclusion, preventing them from advancing.

**Summoning Daoist Adepts**
From *Biographies of Daoist Scholars, Scroll Seven*:
Lu Xiujing, styled Yuande, was a native of Dongqian in Wu Commandery. He secluded himself on Mount Lu’s Waterfall Mountain to cultivate the Dao. Emperor Ming of the Liu-Song, desiring to propagate Daoist teachings, widely sought those of eminent virtue. Admiring the master’s character, he dispatched envoys to summon him. In the third year of the Taishi era (467 CE), the emperor issued an edict to Wang Jingzong, Governor of Jiangzhou, ordering him to urge the master’s journey to the capital with all due courtesy. The master declined on grounds of illness, yet the edicts came repeatedly. Though the emperor could not secure his presence, his admiration only deepened. Imperial messengers followed one another in an unbroken stream, for his arrival was deemed inevitable.

chunks.original_text: 先生乃曰：主上聪明，远览至不肖，猥见采拾，仰惟洪春，俯深惭惕，老子尚委王官以辅周室，仙公替金锡佐吴朝，得道高真犹且屈己，余亦何人，宁可独善乎？ 即命弟子陈飘之出都也。 初至九江，九江王问道佛得失同异，先生答在佛为留秦，在道为玉皇，斯亦殊途一致耳。 王公称善，至都勑主书计林子宣旨，令住后堂，先生不乐，权住骠骑航扈客子精舍，劳问相望，朝野欣属。 天子乃命司徒建安王尚书令袁粲设广咽之礼，置招贤座，盛延朝彦，广集时英，会于庄严佛寺。 时玄言之士飞辩河注，硕学沙门抗论锋出，椅角李释，竞相诘难。 先生标理约辞，解纷挫锐。 王公嗟忭，遐迩悦服。 坐毕，奏议於人主。 旬日间，又请会於华林延贤之馆。 帝亲临幸，王公毕集。 先生鹿巾谒帝而升，天子肃然增敬，躬自问道，谘求宗极。 先生标阐玄门，敷释流统，并诣希微，莫非妙范。 帝心悦焉。 王公又问，都不闻道家说二世？ 先生答经云：吾不知谁之子，象帝之先。 既已有先，居然有后。 既有先后，居然有中。 庄子云：方生方死，此并明三世。 但言约理玄，世未能悟耳！ 朝廷欲要之以荣，先生眇然不顾。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master then declared: "His Majesty is wise and far-seeing, yet deigns to regard one as unworthy as I with favor. Gazing upward, I feel the vastness of spring’s generosity; looking downward, I am deeply ashamed and fearful. Even Laozi relinquished his post as royal archivist to aid the Zhou court, and the Perfected Immortal [Zhang Daoling] set aside his golden seal and bamboo tablet to assist the Wu dynasty. Those who have attained the Dao and become lofty perfected ones still humble themselves—what am I, that I alone should preserve my own integrity?" Thereupon, he commanded his disciple Chen Piaozhi to journey to the capital.

Upon first arriving in Jiujiang, the Prince of Jiujiang inquired of him regarding the similarities and differences between Buddhism and Daoism. The Master replied: "In Buddhism, it is the *Liushen* [‘Retained in Qin’]; in Daoism, it is the Jade Emperor—these are but different paths leading to the same end." The prince and his ministers praised his words.

Upon reaching the capital, the emperor ordered the Director of the Imperial Secretariat, Ji Lin Zixuan, to convey his decree, bidding the Master reside in the Rear Hall. The Master found no joy in this and temporarily stayed at the *Biaoqi Hanghu Kezi* Abode. Imperial messengers bearing inquiries came in an unbroken stream, and both court and common folk rejoiced in anticipation.

Thereafter, the emperor commanded the Minister over the Masses, the Prince of Jian’an, and the President of the Imperial Secretariat, Yuan Can, to prepare a grand banquet of wide embrace, setting forth a seat to welcome worthies. Eminent scholars of the age were broadly assembled, and the finest minds of the time gathered at the solemn Buddhist monastery. At that time, masters of profound discourse let their eloquence flow like rivers, and learned śramaṇas advanced their arguments with sharp brilliance. Daoists and Buddhists vied in debate, each posing challenges to the other. The Master, however, set forth principles with concise words, resolving entanglements and blunting sharpness. The prince and his ministers sighed in admiration, and all present, near and far, were pleased and convinced.

When the gathering concluded, a memorial was presented to the emperor. Within ten days, another assembly was convened at the *Hualin Yanxian* Pavilion. The emperor personally attended, and all the princes and ministers gathered. The Master, wearing a deer-hide cap, paid his respects to the emperor and ascended. The Son of Heaven grew even more reverent, personally inquiring of the Dao and seeking the ultimate principle. The Master expounded upon the mysteries of the Daoist gate, elucidating its traditions and lineages, all of which reached the subtlest and most profound, none failing to embody wondrous standards. The emperor’s heart was delighted.

The prince and his ministers then asked: "We have never heard Daoists speak of the two ages [past and future]." The Master replied: "The scriptures say, ‘I know not whose child it is, but it resembles the ancestor of the Emperor.’ Since there is an ancestor, there is clearly a descendant. Since there is an ancestor and a descendant, there is clearly a middle. Zhuangzi said, ‘As it is born, so it dies’—this also clarifies the three ages. Yet the words are few and the principle profound; the world has not yet awakened to it."

The court sought to entice him with honors, but the Master remained distant and unmoved.

chunks.original_text: 宋帝乃於北郊筑崇虚馆以礼之，盛兴造构，广延胜侣。 先生乃大敞法门，深弘典奥，朝野注意，道俗归心。 道教之兴，於斯为盛也。 第八卷云：陶弘景，字通明，魏郡平阳人也。 笃好黄老，备参道法，自称华阳隐居。 初憩句容县之句曲山，登岩告静。 及齐明帝践祚，恐幽祇未协，固请隐居诣诸名岳，望袟展敬，遂周旋五郡，经历三年，事讫迎还，令憩钟岭，使人往来，月有数四，饷赐重迭，随意所求，朝野书疏交为烦黩也。 第九卷云：齐建武二年，陶受勑东祈名山，困寻经典也。 又云：蒋负刍，义兴人也。 去来茅山，有志栖托。 齐高帝於山造观，建元二年勑请於崇阳观行道也。 第十二卷云：孟智周，梁武帝时人也，多所该通。 梁静惠王抚临神忮，请智周讲光宅寺，僧法云来，赴发讲法云渊解独步，甚相凌忽，及交往复盛其词辩，智周敷释焕然，僧众叹伏之也。 第十四卷云：孙游岳，字玄达，东阳永康人也。 却粒，饵麻屑、松与木。 齐永明三年，敕征为兴世观主也。 第十六卷云：孔灵产，会稽山阴人也。 深研道要，遍览仙籍。 宋明帝於禹穴之侧立怀仙观，诏使居焉。 迁太中大夫，加给事高皇，赐以鹿巾猥裘竹素之器。 手诏曰：君有古人之风，赐以林下之服，登凡之日可以相存之也。 第十九卷云：徐师子，字德威，东海人也。 陈武帝立宗虚大观，引师子以为观主。 后六七年卒于馆，文皇勑责秘器并无，常与凡厥丧事皆取给台焉。 投山水龙简品 《洞神经第十四》云：凡学长生存神明者，山仁水智，动静所依。 依仁者，静而寿也； 依智者，动而乐也。 乐近水，寿如山。 山居玩水，长生之方也。 当投简送名，拜见山水之灵。 灵皇帝君，佑护善人，使弘仁智，长生神仙也。 八节日寅午时，朱书白槿简一枚，曰：曾孙某州郡县乡里位姓名，志求长生，移籍太清，改死录，着生符。 计字满简，诣山向王烧香，发炉再拜，读简毕，再拜长跪，青纸裹，青丝缠，再拜岩石上，勿令人见，复炉还，勿反顾也。 诣水泛舟中流，再拜讫，向王发炉心拜，读简毕又拜，裹缠如法，以净石系之，令沈。 立春为始，三年二十四过，必能降真。 若公私意外一节致阙者，更从初始。 数满未感，功少行粗，更勤立功，精谨修之。 久久神降，自知吉凶，幽显了然，道成乃止也。 《赤书玉诀上》云：元始灵宝告水帝，削除罪简。 上法曰：灵宝黄帝先生，某甲年如干岁某月某日生，愿神愿仙，长生不死，三元同存。 九府水帝、十二河源、江海淮济溟灵大神，乞削罪名，上闻九天，请诣水府，金龙驿传，某年月朔日，子於某国土地告文。 右朱书银木简上，以青纸裹简，青丝缠之，金龙负简以投三河之渊。 初用金钮九只连简沉之，后投不须。 三过都止，投简当於清泠之渊，北向叩齿三通，读简竟祝曰： 元始五老上帝高尊、十方至真、太华灵仙，赤文告命，无幽不开，上御九天，请下玉文，日月五星、北斗七元； 中告五岳四方灵山，下告河海，十二水源、九府水帝、溟灵大神。 今日上告，万愿开陈，请投玉简，乞削罪名，千曾万祖，九族种亲，罪相连染，及得我身，普蒙削除，绝灭种根，记名水府，言上帝前，七祖父母，去离八难，上登九天，衣饭自然，我罪释散，万神咸闻，请以金龙，关盟水官，请如所陈，金龙驿传。
chunks.translated_text:
The Song emperor then built the Hall of Lofty Emptiness north of the capital to honor him, constructing grand edifices and widely inviting eminent companions. There, the Master broadly opened the gates of the Dao, deeply expounding its arcane classics. Court and commoner alike turned their attention to him, and both Daoists and layfolk gave him their hearts. The flourishing of Daoist teachings reached its zenith in this era.

Volume Eight states: Tao Hongjing, styled Tongming, was a native of Pingyang in Wei Commandery. Devoted to the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, he thoroughly studied the methods of the Dao and styled himself the Recluse of Huayang. Initially, he rested at Mount Gouqu in Jurong County, ascending its cliffs to seek stillness. When Emperor Ming of Qi ascended the throne, fearing discord with the hidden spirits, he urgently requested the Recluse to visit the renowned sacred peaks, offering prayers and paying respects. Thus, Tao traveled through five commanderies over three years. Upon completing his tasks, he was welcomed back and allowed to rest at Mount Zhongling. Messengers came and went several times a month, bearing lavish gifts and provisions, fulfilling every request. The court and common folk alike inundated him with letters, their frequency becoming burdensome.

Volume Nine states: In the second year of Jianwu under the Qi, Tao received an imperial edict to pray at the eastern sacred mountains and exhaustively seek the scriptures. It also states: Jiang Fuchu, a native of Yixing, came and went from Mount Mao, aspiring to dwell there. Emperor Gao of Qi built an abbey on the mountain, and in the second year of Jianyuan, he issued an edict inviting Jiang to perform Daoist rites at Chongyang Abbey.

Volume Twelve states: Meng Zhizhou, a man of Emperor Wu of Liang’s time, was broadly learned. Prince Jinghui of Liang governed Shenji and invited Zhizhou to lecture at Guangzhai Temple. When the monk Fayun arrived, he initiated the discourse. Fayun’s profound understanding was unmatched, and he treated Zhizhou with disdain. Yet as they exchanged words, Zhizhou’s expositions shone brilliantly, and the assembly of monks marveled and submitted to him.

Volume Fourteen states: Sun Youyue, styled Xuanda, was a native of Yongkang in Dongyang. He abstained from grains, consuming hemp fibers, pine, and wood. In the third year of Yongming under the Qi, he was summoned by edict to serve as abbot of Xingshi Abbey.

Volume Sixteen states: Kong Lingchan, a native of Shanyin in Kuaiji, deeply studied the essentials of the Dao and perused the entire corpus of immortals’ texts. Emperor Ming of Song established Huaixian Abbey beside the Yu Cavern and decreed that Kong reside there. He was later promoted to Grand Master for Splendid Happiness, granted the title Gentleman of the Palace, and bestowed with a deer-fur cap, a coarse fur robe, and bamboo and silk vessels. The emperor’s handwritten edict read: “You possess the bearing of the ancients. I grant you the attire of a recluse. On the day of your ascent, you may come to visit me.”

Volume Nineteen states: Xu Shizi, styled Dewei, was a native of Donghai. When Emperor Wu of Chen established Zongxu Abbey, he appointed Shizi as its abbot. Six or seven years later, Shizi passed away at the abbey. Emperor Wen issued an edict reproaching the lack of funerary provisions, and thereafter, all matters concerning his burial were supplied by the imperial court.

**Ritual of Presenting Tablets to Mountains and Waters**
*The Fourteenth Scripture of the Cavernous Spirit* states: Those who study long life and preserve the luminous spirits must rely on the benevolence of mountains and the wisdom of waters, for these are the foundations of movement and stillness. To rely on benevolence is to be still and long-lived; to rely on wisdom is to be active and joyful. Joy is near water, longevity like mountains. Dwelling in mountains and delighting in waters is the method of long life. One should present tablets bearing one’s name and pay homage to the spirits of mountains and waters. The numinous sovereigns of the emperors protect the virtuous, enabling them to cultivate benevolence and wisdom and attain long life as divine immortals.

On the eight seasonal nodes at the hours of *yin* and *wu*, write in cinnabar on a white hibiscus tablet: “Your humble descendant, [name], of [state, commandery, county, village, and rank], seeks long life, transfers his register to the Great Clarity, alters the record of death, and inscribes the talisman of life.” When the tablet is filled, face the mountain’s king, burn incense, open the censer, bow twice, read the tablet, bow twice again, and kneel. Wrap the tablet in blue paper, bind it with blue silk, bow twice more, and place it upon a rock. Let no one witness this. Close the censer and depart without looking back.

For waters, board a boat and drift to the center of the current. Bow twice, then face the water’s king, open the censer, bow from the heart, read the tablet, bow again, wrap and bind it as before, and tie it to a clean stone to sink it. Beginning at the start of spring, perform this twenty-four times over three years, and you will surely summon the perfected. If, due to public or private matters, you miss a single node, begin anew. If the count is complete but no response comes, your merit is slight and your conduct coarse—redouble your efforts and cultivate with precision. Over time, spirits will descend, and you will know good and ill fortune, understanding both the hidden and manifest. Cease only when the Dao is achieved.

*The Upper Jade Instructions of the Red Writ* states: The Primordial Numinous Treasure addressed the Water Sovereign, cutting away the tablet of sins. The superior method is as follows: “The Yellow Emperor of the Numinous Treasure, [your name], aged [years], born on [month, day], yearns for divine transcendence and long life without death, with the Three Origins preserved together. O Nine Prefectures’ Water Sovereign, Twelve River Sources, and the great spirits of the Jiang, Hai, Huai, and Ji rivers and the vast seas, I beseech you to erase my sinful name, report it to the Nine Heavens, and present it to the Water Palace. By golden dragon courier, [your name] submits this announcement to the local earth god of [state] on the first day of [month, year].”

Write this in cinnabar on a silverwood tablet, wrap it in blue paper, bind it with blue silk, and have a golden dragon bear the tablet into the depths of the Three Rivers. Initially, attach nine golden clasps to the tablet before sinking it; thereafter, this is unnecessary. After three presentations, cease. Cast the tablet into a clear, cold abyss, face north, click your teeth three times, and upon finishing the reading, pray: “Supreme and exalted Five Elder Lords of the Primordial Beginning, perfected beings of the ten directions, divine immortals of Mount Taihua, the Red Writ’s proclamation opens all that is hidden. Ascending to the Nine Heavens, I request the descent of the Jade Writ, the sun, moon, and five planets, the Northern Dipper’s seven origins. In the center, I announce this to the Five Peaks and the sacred mountains of the four directions; below, to the rivers and seas, the Twelve Water Sources, the Nine Prefectures’ Water Sovereign, and the great spirits of the vast seas. Today, I make this supreme announcement, unfolding ten thousand wishes. I present the jade tablet, beseeching the erasure of my sins, those of my thousand ancestors and ten thousand forebears, the nine clans and all kin, and the sins that have stained me. May all be universally erased, their roots severed, their names recorded in the Water Palace and proclaimed before the Emperor. May my seven generations of ancestors depart from the Eight Difficulties and ascend to the Nine Heavens, clothed and fed by nature. May my sins be released and dispersed, known to all spirits. I entreat the golden dragon to bind the Water Officials in covenant. As I have stated, let the golden dragon courier transmit this.”

ter replied: "The scriptures say, ‘I know not whose child it is, but it resembles the ancestor of the Emperor.’ Since there is an ancestor, there is clearly a descendant. Since there is an ancestor and a descendant, there is clearly a middle. Zhuangzi said, ‘As it is born, so it dies’—this also clarifies the three ages. Yet the words are few and the principle profound; the world has not yet awakened to it."

The court sought to entice him with honors, but the Master remained distant and unmoved.

chunks.original_text: 又云：元始灵宝告五岳灵山，除罪求仙。 上法曰：灵宝黄帝先生，某甲年如干岁某月生，命属黄帝，名系太山，愿神愿仙，长生度世，飞行上清。 五岳真人，至神至灵，乞削罪籍，上名九天。 请诣灵山，金龙驿传。 某年月朔日，子於某国某岳告文。 右朱书银木简，青纸裹之，青丝缠，金钮九只，金龙埋本命之岳，悉如上法。 於本命之岳，东向叩齿九通，读简竟祝曰： 玄老开明，元始监真。 上帝五老，赤书丹文。 天地本始，总．领三元。 摄气召会，催促举仙。 高上符命，一道十天。 日月星宿，五岳灵山。 天下地上，溟灵太神，监生主录，南上三门。 关领玉简，勒名舟编。 削落罪书，上补帝臣。 千曾万祖，九族种亲，皆蒙解脱五道八难，去离三恶，魂升九天，生死开度，万劫长存。 今日上告，万神咸闻。 请以金钮，关盟真官。 请如所告，金龙驿传。 又云：元始灵宝，告九地土皇，灭罪言名求仙。 上法曰：灵宝黄帝先生，某甲年若干岁某月生，命系九天，中斗领籍，愿神愿仙，长生度世，飞行上清。 中皇九地，戊己黄神，土府五帝，乞削罪录，勒上太玄，请诣中宫，投简记名，今愿自信，金龙驿传。 某年某月朔日，子於某郡国乡里中告文也。 右朱书银木简，青纸裹之，青丝缠，金钮九只，金龙一枚，埋所住中宫，悉如上法。 於中庭向王叩齿十二通，读简竟祝曰： 天开地张，九气分灵。 三光同符，十方朗清。 五老上帝，开真领生。 丹书玉文，尧始上精。 普告天下，九土皇灵。 今日上告，万仙定生。 我愿我仙，请投玉名。 土府太皇，勒除罪刑。 奏简上宫、列簿华青。 升得飞腾，天地同灵。 九族种亲，腐骸更荣。 魂升南宫，受化仙庭。 吉日告命，万神咸听。 请以金钮，表盟至情。 请如所告，金龙驿传。 道言：欲度诸天人民，便离五道八难之中，得过三恶，世世与道相值。 当以八节甲子之日投三元玉简，除宿罪簿，言名上天。 事事三过诸天，三官九府，更相属寄，上天友别，万神敬护，五帝侍卫，三界司迎，门户整肃，天下地神日月来朝，千魔万精不敢妄干，志愿坚白，触向咸成。 七祖父母即得解脱三涂五苦，上升天堂。 生死福庆，影响相酬。 三官九府，书人功过，其理甚明也。 三洞珠囊卷之二竟 三洞珠囊卷之三

It is further stated: The Primordial Numinous Treasure announces to the Five Marchmounts and the sacred mountains, seeking the erasure of sins and the attainment of transcendence.

The supreme method declares: The Numinous Treasure Yellow Emperor Master, so-and-so, born in such-and-such a year, month, and day, of such-and-such age, whose fate is bound to the Yellow Emperor and whose name is registered at Mount Tai, yearns for divine transcendence and immortality, to ascend through the world and soar into the Upper Clarity.

O Perfected Ones of the Five Marchmounts, most divine and numinous, I beseech you to erase my name from the ledgers of sin and inscribe it in the Nine Heavens. I present this petition at the sacred mountain, to be transmitted by the golden dragon courier.

On the first day of such-and-such a month and year, I, the disciple, submit this announcement at such-and-such a state and such-and-such a marchmount.

Inscribe this in vermilion on a silver-wood tablet, wrap it in blue paper, bind it with blue silk, affix nine golden clasps, and bury it with a golden dragon at the marchmount of one’s fate, all in accordance with the above method.

At the marchmount of one’s fate, face east, knock the teeth nine times, and upon finishing the reading of the tablet, recite the prayer:

Mysterious Elder, Radiant and Clear,
Primordial One who oversees the Perfected.
Five Elders of the Emperor,
Vermilion Script and Cinnabar Texts.
Heaven and Earth in their origin,
Governing the Three Primes.
Drawing in qi and summoning assembly,
Hastening the ascent of transcendents.
Supreme talismanic mandate,
A single Dao spanning the Ten Heavens.
Sun, moon, and stellar lodges,
Five Marchmounts and sacred mountains.
Above the heavens, below the earth,
Vast spirits of the deep,
Overseeing life and recording destiny,
At the Southern Three Gates.
Binding the jade tablet,
Inscribing names in the celestial register.
Erasing the books of sin,
Promoting to the ranks of imperial ministers.
A thousand ancestors and ten thousand forebears,
Nine clans and all kin,
All delivered from the Five Paths and Eight Difficulties,
Departing the Three Evils,
Their souls ascending to the Nine Heavens.
Liberated in life and death,
Preserved for ten thousand kalpas.
Today I make this supreme announcement,
Heard by all spirits.
I entreat the golden clasps
To bind the Perfected Officials in covenant.
As I have stated,
Let the golden dragon courier transmit this.

It is further stated: The Primordial Numinous Treasure announces to the Nine Earthly Soil Sovereigns, beseeching the obliteration of sins, the proclamation of names, and the attainment of transcendence.

The supreme method declares: The Numinous Treasure Yellow Emperor Master, so-and-so, born in such-and-such a year, month, and day, of such-and-such age, whose fate is bound to the Nine Heavens and whose register is held by the Central Dipper, yearns for divine transcendence and immortality, to ascend through the world and soar into the Upper Clarity.

O Central August One of the Nine Earths,
Yellow Spirits of Wu and Ji,
Five Emperors of the Soil Palace,
I beseech you to erase my record of sins
And inscribe it in the Great Mystery.
I present this petition at the Central Palace,
Submitting the tablet to record my name.
Today I pledge my sincerity,
To be transmitted by the golden dragon courier.

On the first day of such-and-such a month and year, I, the disciple, submit this announcement at the central precinct of such-and-such a commandery, state, village, and hamlet.

Inscribe this in vermilion on a silver-wood tablet, wrap it in blue paper, bind it with blue silk, affix nine golden clasps and one golden dragon, and bury it at the central palace of one’s dwelling, all in accordance with the above method.

In the central courtyard, face the sovereign, knock the teeth twelve times, and upon finishing the reading of the tablet, recite the prayer:

Heaven unfolds, Earth extends,
Nine qi divide the numinous.
Three luminaries share the same talisman,
Ten directions shine in clarity.
Five Elder Emperors,
Opening the Perfected and governing life.
Cinnabar Script and Jade Texts,
Yao’s primordial essence ascends.
Universally announced to the world,
Nine Soil Sovereigns and numinous spirits.
Today I make this supreme announcement,
All transcendents confirm my birth.
I yearn for my divine transcendence,
I present my jade name.
Great August One of the Soil Palace,
Erase my sins and punishments.
Submit the tablet to the Upper Palace,
Inscribe it in the registers of Splendor and Azure.
Ascend and soar,
Heaven and Earth share the numinous.
Nine clans and all kin,
Their decayed bones renewed in glory.
Their souls ascend to the Southern Palace,
Transformed in the transcendent courts.
On this auspicious day, I proclaim my mandate,
Heard by all spirits.
I entreat the golden clasps
To manifest the covenant of utmost sincerity.
As I have stated,
Let the golden dragon courier transmit this.

The Dao declares: To deliver the people of all heavens, liberating them from the Five Paths and Eight Difficulties, enabling them to pass beyond the Three Evils, and ensuring they encounter the Dao in every lifetime, one must present the Three Prime Jade Tablets on the days of the Eight Nodal Points and the jiazi cycle, erasing the ledgers of past sins and proclaiming names to Heaven. Each matter is to be presented three times before all heavens, the Three Officials, and the Nine Palaces, with successive transmissions and separate submissions to Heaven. All spirits will revere and protect, the Five Emperors will attend, the Three Realms will receive and welcome, gates and thresholds will be ordered, the earthly spirits of the world and the deities of sun and moon will come to pay homage. A thousand demons and ten thousand spirits dare not rashly interfere. With resolve firm and pure, all aspirations will be fulfilled. Seven generations of ancestors will be delivered from the Three Wretched Paths and the Five Sufferings, ascending to the Heavenly Halls. The blessings of life and death will reciprocate like echoes. The Three Officials and Nine Palaces record the merits and transgressions of people—this principle is most clear.

The second scroll of *The Pearl Satchel of the Three Caverns* concludes.
The third scroll of *The Pearl Satchel of the Three Caverns* begins.

chunks.original_text: 大唐陆海羽客王悬河修 服食品 《列仙传下》云：断食休根以除谷气，呼吸导引吐故纳新。 《内音玉字上》云：子欲为神仙不死，当去三虫，心下伏尸，常以夜半鸡呜祝曰： 东方青牙，服食青牙，饮以朝华，三咽止。 南方朱丹，服食朱丹，饮以丹池，三咽止。 中央之野，戊己昂昂，服食精气，饮以醴泉，三咽止。 西方明石，服食明石，饮以灵液，三咽止。 北方玄滋，服食玄滋，饮以玉饴，三咽止。 如此三十日，三虫皆死，伏尸走去。 正神正气自然定，伏尸不复还心中，兆自仙矣。 此为五方五牙之法。 此即是五厨也。 故老子《五厨经》：修奉太和，不亏不盈。 尝之无味，嗅之无馨，子得闻之，命合真星，一受不退，长乐自然是也。 又《太上黄素四十四方经》亦有此食祝之文也。 《天文上经》云：玄古之人所以寿考者，造次之间不食谷也。 《大有经》曰：五谷是刳命之凿，腐臭五藏，致命促缩。 此根入口，无希久寿，汝欲不死，肠中无滓也。 《道学传第七》云：陆修静，字元德，吴兴东迁人也。 虽外混世务，内守贞朴，少已习断谷，别床独处也。 第十六卷云：陶炎，字爱静，庐江浔阳人也。 年十五六，服食绝谷，初犹食面，后唯食枣也。 《灵宝斋戒威仪经诀下》云：道士食五谷，断无所饵则饥。 若服药物，正中服之，过中听饮清水，饮而绝食。 平旦饮粥，日中菜食。 《大真科下》云：受外内治录学仙之人，皆当服食咽气，却恶治病。 未能断谷者，食宜有常，旦粥也，中羹饭也，乾蔬盥豉，示止饥而已，不得适口贪香，美滋味，慎勿杀生，肥鲜狼藉。 至於酱醋，亦不可多，多则损性。 又不得过饱，恒令限少一两口乃为佳也。 食已便行，逍遥调适。 临食食讫，悉存先圣洪恩，垂逮衔荷无穷，普念一切成同饱满，当得甘露芝液，无饥不复食啖世间尘味。 若受他施食，皆惭谢主人。 心口愿念施主富乐，饱满长年，同得法味，永兔灾衰，无饥渴想。 常有法食及世间食，施与一切，无有穷尽，济度舍气，不生悔吝，终无嫌恨长共欢乐。 初食食讫，出饭布散山水之中、岩林之下、篱墙之边，勿掷屋上，虫乌发穿，致漏弊也。 《太上黄素四十方经》云：凡道士临食，当以左手持箸，琢盘三过，乃微祝曰：二玄上道，四极清冷。 太一帝君，百神黄宁。 受根三宫，溉灌脾灵。 上飨太和，餐味五馨。 魂胎之命，七液流停，百关通和，五藏华明。 双皇合景，飞行上清。 食毕，又琢盘三过，此名为魂胎受馨百神飨根之道，常能行之，令人神明气和，魂魄安宁，辟恶除试，常保利贞。 《神仙传第九》云：介象，字元则，会稽人也。 入山见仙女象，叩头求乞长生。 女曰：汝血食之气未尽，断谷三年，更来，吾上於此待汝。 象归，断谷三年更来，乃复往也。 此女故在前处，乃以《还丹经》一首以授象，合象曰：得此便得仙，勿复他为也。 《九华经》云：曰者，霞之实也，霞者，日之精也。 服之体生玉光，霞映上清之法也。 《三皇斋仪》云：修道之人，日中一食，夜半生气时食，此日夜两食，皆取生气时，避死气时也。 他时纤毫不得安尝，必犯死气也。 若疾患采药，或服饵休粮，各随所宜，不拘制限。 夫食以养身，身安神乐，不饥之者修学易成，饿困虚赢功业不就也。
chunks.translated_text:
Master Wang Xuanhe of the Vast Ocean of Lu, Feathered Guest of the Great Tang, on the Methods of Ingesting and Consuming:

*The Biographies of the Immortals, Lower Scroll* states: "Cease eating and rest the roots to expel grain-qi. Through breathwork and guiding the qi, exhale the old and inhale the new."

*The Upper Scroll of Jade Characters of Inner Sounds* states: "If you wish to become an immortal and not die, you must expel the Three Worms and the corpse-worm lurking beneath the heart. Regularly at midnight and cock’s crow, recite this invocation:

*To the Azure Fang of the East, consume the Azure Fang, drink the morning blossom—three swallows, then stop.
To the Vermilion Cinnabar of the South, consume the Vermilion Cinnabar, drink from the Cinnabar Pool—three swallows, then stop.
To the Central Wilds, where Wu and Ji rise high, consume the essence-qi, drink from the Sweet Spring—three swallows, then stop.
To the Luminous Stone of the West, consume the Luminous Stone, drink the numinous liquid—three swallows, then stop.
To the Mystic Nourishment of the North, consume the Mystic Nourishment, drink the Jade Syrup—three swallows, then stop.*

After thirty days of this, the Three Worms will all die, and the corpse-worm will flee. The true spirit and true qi will naturally settle; the corpse-worm will no longer return to the heart, and you shall become an immortal. This is the method of the Five Directions and Five Fangs—it is also the Five Kitchens. Thus, the *Scripture of the Five Kitchens* by Laozi states: 'Cultivate and uphold the Great Harmony, neither deficient nor excessive. Taste it and find no flavor; smell it and find no fragrance. If you come to know this, your destiny aligns with the true stars. Once received, it is never lost, and eternal joy arises naturally.' The *Forty-Four Methods Scripture of the Yellow Plain* also contains this text on ingesting and invoking."

*The Upper Scripture of Astronomy* states: "The reason the people of remote antiquity lived long was that they did not consume grains even in haste."

*The Scripture of Great Possession* says: "The Five Grains are the chisels that hollow out life, rotting the five viscera and shortening the lifespan. Once these roots enter the mouth, do not hope for longevity. If you desire not to die, keep your intestines free of filth."

*The Seventh Scroll of the Transmission of Daoist Learning* states: "Lu Xiujing, styled Yuande, was a native of Dongqian in Wuxing. Though outwardly he mingled with worldly affairs, inwardly he preserved purity and simplicity. From youth, he practiced grain avoidance and slept alone."

The sixteenth scroll states: "Tao Yan, styled Aijing, was a native of Xunyang in Lujiang. At fifteen or sixteen, he consumed and ceased grains, initially still eating wheat flour, later only jujubes."

*The Lower Scroll of the Essential Rites of the Numinous Treasure Fast* states: "If Daoists eat the Five Grains but take no other sustenance, they will hunger. If consuming medicinal substances, take them precisely at noon; after noon, drink only clear water and cease eating. At dawn, drink congee; at midday, eat vegetables."

*The Lower Scroll of the Great Perfection Regulations* states: "Those who study the records of external and internal cultivation to learn immortality should all consume and swallow qi to repel evil and cure illness. For those who cannot yet cease grains, meals should be regular: congee at dawn, vegetable stew and rice at midday, with dried vegetables and fermented beans—enough only to stave off hunger, not to indulge in rich flavors or fine tastes. Take care never to kill living beings or waste fat and fresh foods. As for sauces and vinegar, these too must not be overused, for excess harms one’s nature. Moreover, do not overeat; it is best to stop one or two mouthfuls short. After eating, walk leisurely to aid digestion. Before and after meals, meditate on the boundless grace of the ancient sages, whose beneficence endures without end. Universally wish that all beings attain fullness and satisfaction, that they may receive the sweet dew and mushroom nectar, never hunger again, and no longer crave the dusty flavors of the world. If accepting food from others, feel humility and gratitude toward the host. With heart and mouth, wish the donor wealth, joy, fullness, and long life, that they too may partake of the flavor of the Dao, forever free from calamity and decline, without hunger or thirst. Always have Dharma-food and worldly food to offer all beings without end, aiding and liberating them with generosity, free from regret or stinginess, never harboring resentment, forever sharing joy. After the first meal, scatter rice in the mountains and waters, beneath cliffs and forests, or beside fences and walls—never toss it onto rooftops, lest insects and birds peck through and cause leaks and decay."

*The Scripture of the Forty-Four Methods of the Yellow Plain* states: "Whenever Daoists are about to eat, they should hold their chopsticks in the left hand, tap the plate three times, and softly invoke: *'The Two Mysteries ascend the Dao, the Four Poles are clear and cool. The Supreme One, the Lord Emperor, and the hundred spirits are at peace. Receive the roots of the Three Palaces, irrigate and nourish the numinous spleen. Partake of the Great Harmony, feast on the five fragrances. The life of the soul-embryo, the seven fluids flow and settle; the hundred passages harmonize, the five viscera bloom with radiance. The Twin Sovereigns merge with the light, soaring to ascend the Upper Clarity.'* After eating, tap the plate three more times—this is called the Way of the Soul-Embryo receiving fragrance and the hundred spirits feasting on the roots. Practicing this regularly makes one’s spirit bright and qi harmonious, the hun and po at peace, repelling evil and dispelling trials, forever preserving good fortune and purity."

*The Ninth Scroll of the Biographies of Divine Immortals* states: "Jie Xiang, styled Yuanze, was a native of Kuaiji. Entering the mountains, he encountered an immortal woman who resembled an image. He kowtowed and begged for longevity. The woman said: *'Your qi from blood and food is not yet exhausted. Cease grains for three years, then return—I will await you here.'* Xiang returned home, ceased grains for three years, and went back. The woman was still in the same place and gave him a scroll of the *Scripture of the Returning Elixir*, saying: *'Attain this, and you shall become an immortal. Do nothing else.'*"

*The Scripture of the Nine Radiances* states: "Jujubes are the fruit of the rosy clouds; rosy clouds are the essence of the sun. Consuming them, the body generates jadelike radiance—this is the method of reflecting the Upper Clarity."

*The Rituals of the Three Sovereigns’ Fasts* states: "Those who cultivate the Dao eat once at midday and once at the hour of living qi at midnight. These two meals, day and night, are taken at the hour of living qi to avoid the hour of dead qi. At other times, not even the slightest morsel may be tasted, for it would violate the dead qi. If ill or gathering herbs, or consuming medicines to cease grains, follow what is appropriate without rigid constraints. Food is for nourishing the body; when the body is at ease, the spirit is joyful. Those who are not hungry find cultivation easy to accomplish; those weakened by hunger and emaciation will not achieve their work."

chunks.original_text: 又云：一食道时，皆烧香以存，供养先圣，临目思见前神降见，歆飨良久，愿念施及一切，咸同饱满。 《洞玄五符经》云：食月之精可以长生，食星之精上升太清也。 《登真隐诀第二》云：服云牙，可绝谷去尸也。 《登真隐诀第四》云：服云牙，可修真一之道，守元咽液。 若似饥，当食面物，以渐遗谷却粒，不得一日顿弃，所谓损之又损之，以致於无为也。 《金简玉字经》云：服食断谷者，忌食酒肉及五辛之菜，皆当沐浴，洁衣烧香也。 亦见《大有妙经》也。 《太一洞真玄经》云：子既不能服食去谷、清肠研真者，且当节诸臊秽血腥，杂食荤辛之菜一为禁绝者，可以度生命之长也。 又云：紫微真仙王夫人劝服木叙云：真人养生，太上所宝。 七经五华，二淳内道。 演出，服御众药，采释百草，禳疠固命，木为最好。 流激百邪，消疾耐老。 体生光润，充肌填脑。 非夫勤慕可得，谓无天然，不为术方必也枯槁矣。 又云：养性驻年，玄发不变，此木家之所治也。 又云：夫木乃辟塞邪津，气遏鬼路矣。 餐其九饵则灵心四数，荣卫轻盈。 服其煎散，百疾廖除，可以长生久视也。 合术之方为文多，故此不写出也。 又云：以两手摩拭面目，今小热，以为常，每欲数也。 人之将老面皱者，先从两目下始也，人之体二气少者，先从两鼻间始也。 谓此二处皱衰之户，人气力之关津，故起居常行此法，以辟皱衰，而气力常保康和也。 《太平经第一百一十四》云：青童君采飞根，吞日景，服开明灵符，服月华符，服除二符，拘三魂，制七魄，佩星象符，服华丹，服黄水，服回水，食镮刚，食凤脑，食松梨，食李枣，曰银紫金，服云腴，食竹笋，佩五神符，备此变化无穷，超凌三界之外，游浪六合之中。 《登真隐诀第七》云：服五石者，亦能一日九食，百关流淳，亦能终岁不饥，还老反婴。 遇食则食，不食亦平，真上仙之妙方，断谷之奇灵也。 陶隐居注云：虽一日九食而吸响，流变不变，不为津，终岁不饭而容色更鲜。 青君曰：干石□饭，东青朱英，一服立使人长算千祀，日服日延。 又清灵真人说：霍山中有学道者邓伯元、王玄甫，受服青精□饭、吞日景之法，用思房以来积三十四年，乃内见五藏，冥中夜书。 又云：三蒸青饭，非常来也。 又云：食面乃易减谷也，或补实易充耳。 肠胃填满，不复虚疏。 服□饭，百害不能伤，疾疾不能干，去诸思念，绝三尸，耳目聪明，行步轻腾也。 注云：丹青和神养气，能御却灾疠，故疾害不复犯，既精魂谐乐，无有忧悲杂念，肴谷既休，尸虫自然消绝，肝肾清润，耳目莹彻，筋强骨劲，行动如飞。 又云：凶年无谷，或穷不能得者，皆单服南烛，或和茯苓，或以蜜和南烛，或杂松栢叶也。 又云：夫断谷不必长生。 必须断谷者，盖以遵修灵妙，息肴休根之累，服御药石，求易效之致。 又云：因谷以断谷化六府於毫渐。 又云：吸引之易感，无贵於七曜； 修行之早成，不过於九道； 保守之贞固，弗踰於镇生； 卫用之急防，莫超於浑神； 药石之速效，岂胜於青精； 祈拜之至感，孰贤於朝谢也。 服五石，镇五藏，若暂死，白骨如玉，七魄营侍，二魂守宅，三元欢息，大神内闭，外注皮肉，假来附身，故并应散朽，但使藏府不坏，色状如生，骨髓不枯，筋脑相注，魂魄镇守，三宫晏静，大神既不轮游九变，恒内闭於洞房，须当生之日乃复周流也。

It further states: "At the hour of the single meal in Daoist practice, one must burn incense in contemplation, making offerings to the former sages. With eyes closed, one visualizes the descent of the prior spirits, who partake of the offering for a long while. One’s wishes and thoughts extend to all beings, that all may be equally sated and fulfilled."

*The Scripture of the Five Wondrous Talismans of the Cavernous Mystery* states: "Consuming the essence of the moon grants longevity; consuming the essence of the stars ascends one to the Grand Clarity."

*The Hidden Instructions for Ascending to Perfection, Second Scroll* states: "Ingesting *yunya* allows one to cease grains and expel the corpse-worms."

*The Hidden Instructions for Ascending to Perfection, Fourth Scroll* states: "Ingesting *yunya* enables the cultivation of the Dao of True Unity, the preservation of primordial qi, and the swallowing of saliva. If hunger arises, one should consume wheat-based foods, gradually reducing grain intake until grains are abandoned entirely. One must not abandon them all at once—this is what is meant by 'diminishing and diminishing again, until reaching non-action.'"

*The Scripture of the Golden Tablet and Jade Characters* states: "Those who consume medicinal substances to cease grains must abstain from wine, meat, and the five pungent vegetables. They should bathe, wear clean clothes, and burn incense." This is also seen in *The Scripture of Great Possession and Wondrous Mystery*.

*The Cavernous Mystery Scripture of the Supreme Unity* states: "If you cannot consume medicinal substances to cease grains and purify the intestines to refine the true, you should at least moderate all foul and bloody meats, as well as mixed foods of pungent and rank vegetables, strictly prohibiting them. This can extend the span of life."

It further states: The Perfected Consort Wang of the Purple Tenuity, a true immortal, advocated the consumption of *muxu*: "For the true person nurturing life, the Most High treasures it. The Seven Classics and Five Effulgences, the Two Pure Internal Dao—all emerge from it. Consuming and employing various medicines, gathering and refining the hundred herbs, warding off pestilence and securing life, *mu* is the finest. It flushes away the hundred evils, dispels illness, and resists aging. The body generates radiant luster, filling the flesh and replenishing the brain. Without diligent devotion, one cannot obtain it—without natural endowment, without methods and recipes, one will surely wither."

It further states: "Nurturing nature and halting aging, preserving the blackness of hair—this is what the *mu* family governs." It also states: "Now, *mu* blocks the paths of evil and obstructs the roads of ghosts. Consuming its nine preparations refines the spirit and quickens the four limbs, making the constructive and defensive qi light and agile. Ingesting its decoctions and powders dispels the hundred illnesses—this enables longevity and enduring vision." The methods for compounding *mu* are numerous, so they are not transcribed here.

It further states: "Rub the face and eyes with both hands until slightly warm, making this a regular practice, to be done frequently. When a person ages, wrinkles first appear below the eyes. When a person’s qi and power wane, it first begins between the nostrils. These two places are the gates of wrinkles and decline, the passes of the body’s qi and strength. Thus, in daily life, one should regularly practice this method to ward off wrinkles and decline, preserving qi and strength in constant harmony."

*The Scripture of Great Peace, Scroll One Hundred Fourteen* states: The Azure Lad gathers *feigen*, swallows solar effulgences, ingests the Luminous Spirit Talisman, the Lunar Splendor Talisman, and the Talisman for Expelling the Two [Demons]. He binds the three *hun*, restrains the seven *po*, wears the Star and Constellation Talisman, consumes *huadan*, drinks Yellow Water and Returning Water, eats *huangang*, consumes phoenix brain, eats pine pears and plum jujubes, ingests silver, purple gold, and cloud fat, eats bamboo shoots, wears the Five Spirit Talismans—with these, his transformations are endless. He transcends beyond the Three Realms, roaming within the Six Directions."

*The Hidden Instructions for Ascending to Perfection, Seventh Scroll* states: "Those who consume the Five Minerals can eat nine times a day, with the hundred passages flowing purely. They can also go a full year without hunger, reverting from old age to infancy. When food is encountered, they eat; when not, they remain at ease. This is the wondrous method of the highest immortals, the marvelous efficacy of ceasing grains." Tao Hongjing’s commentary states: "Though they eat nine times a day, they absorb and exhale without sound, their flow and transformation unchanging, producing no saliva. Though they go a year without eating, their complexion becomes fresher."

The Azure Lad says: "Dry mineral [powder] with rice, mixed with eastern green and vermilion essence—one dose immediately extends a person’s lifespan by a thousand years, with each day’s consumption further prolonging it."

The Perfected of Pure Numinosity also says: On Mount Huo, there were Daoist practitioners Deng Boyuan and Wang Xuanfu, who received the method of consuming *qingjing* [azure essence] rice and swallowing solar effulgences. They practiced this from the time of the Celestial Master Fang until thirty-four years had passed, whereupon they could internally perceive the five viscera and write in darkness at midnight.

It further states: "Thrice-steamed azure rice is not an ordinary food." It also states: "Eating wheat-based foods makes reducing grains easier, or supplementing and filling the body is simple. The intestines and stomach become full, no longer empty and weak. Consuming [azure] rice, the hundred harms cannot injure you, illnesses cannot afflict you. It dispels all distracting thoughts, severs the Three Corpses, sharpens hearing and vision, and lightens the steps."

The commentary states: "Cinnabar and azure harmonize the spirit and nurture qi, enabling one to resist and repel disasters and pestilence. Thus, harms and illnesses no longer assail you. With the essence and *hun* in joyful harmony, there are no worries or sorrowful thoughts. Once grains are abandoned, the corpse-worms naturally dissolve. The liver and kidneys become clear and moist, the ears and eyes bright and penetrating, the sinews strong and bones firm—movement is like flying."

It further states: "In famine years without grain, or when impoverished and unable to obtain it, one may consume *nanzhu* alone, or mix it with *fuling*, or blend *nanzhu* with honey, or combine it with pine and cypress leaves."

It further states: "Ceasing grains does not necessarily grant longevity. The necessity of ceasing grains lies in following the cultivation of numinous wonders, freeing oneself from the burdens of cooked foods and rooted grains, and consuming medicinal minerals to seek swift efficacy."

It further states: "Through grains, one ceases grains, transforming the six bowels gradually." It also states: "For ease of absorption and attraction, nothing surpasses the Seven Luminaries. For swift success in cultivation, nothing exceeds the Nine Ways. For steadfast preservation, nothing surpasses *zhensheng*. For urgent defense and protection, nothing surpasses *hunshen*. For rapid efficacy of medicinal minerals, nothing excels *qingjing*. For utmost responsiveness in prayer and worship, nothing is superior to morning and evening offerings."

Those who consume the Five Minerals stabilize the five viscera. If they briefly die, their white bones become like jade. The seven *po* attend them, the two *hun* guard their dwelling, the Three Primes rejoice in rest, the great spirits close within, and externally, they infuse the skin and flesh. Though the body may decay, if the viscera and bowels remain unharmed, their appearance and form remain as in life. The bone marrow does not wither, the sinews and brain interflow, the *hun* and *po* stand guard, the Three Palaces are tranquil and still. Since the great spirits no longer roam the Nine Transformations but remain closed within the Cavern Chamber, they will only resume their circulation on the destined day of rebirth.

chunks.original_text: 或四十年、二十年、十年、三年，随意而出。 当生之时，即便收血育肉，生津成液，复质成形，乃胜於昔未死之容。 真人炼身於大阴，易貌於三官，此之谓也。 天帝君云：太阴炼身形胜，服九转丹，形容端且严，面色似灵云，上登太极阙，爱书为真人也。 又引九华安妃曰：忧累靡干於玄宅，哀念莫扰於绛津，淡泊眇观，顾景共欢，俯仰四运，日得成真，视眇所涯，皆已合神。 正月四日、三月十五日、四月八日、六月四日、七月七日、八月八日、九月九日、十月五日、十一月三日、十二月十二日，并朝玉是也。 正月九日、二月八日、三月七日、四月六日、五月五日、六月四日、七月二日、八月二日、九月一日、十月十日、十一月十一日、十二月十二日，并朝太素也。 正月一日、二月二十日、三月二十七日、六月六日、八月二十日、十一月三日、十二月六日，并朝太极也。 月七日、十一日、十五日，存玄丹。 月一日、十一日、十六日、二十一日、二十六日，存宝镜。 存宝镜者，存见两目变成两明镜，照我一体也。 月一日、十五日、二十七日，服明堂符、皇象符。 丁卯日，朝青童君。 建、除日，存三一。 寅时，存上景符三部，服玄真。 卯日，服雾，服日象，仍服日芒，服七星符、解化符，朝太微，朝玉晨，服三气足龙。 戌时，服月精，服玄真，服月芒。 亥时，吸水，祝三云，祝五笋，祝六宫，存大君，卧祝剑环，仍存斗，存下景，存头五。 辰丑时存双景，皆是修道之方也。 又云：升玄飞步回谢，拘魂制魄，亦是其方也。 《上清消魔经》云：琅牙郁华，七阳日婴，九琳之液，八琼之精，四蕊紫浆，五珠降生三华飞刚，双珠月明，兰液金，甘露玉瓶，神蕖丹散，云柯连营，琅圩朝结，西皇素盈，漱而变之，以入紫庭。 又云：东极织女之水，西尽长庚虞渊，南穷阳光之根，北测太阴液城。 又云：北采玄廓之绮柰，仰漱云山之朱蜜； 东掇扶桑之丹椹，俯探长渊之文藻。 上和九转之飞玉，下咽青玄之霞宝。 太虚结镮，素婴怀抱，紫虬童子，九包凤脑，太极隐芝，绛树日道，太上虹李，天汉大草，南宫巨珠，西卿扶老，三梁龙华，灵妃所讨，有得食之，分神亿道。 又云； 上清幽芝太和，斑龙黑胎，文虎白沫，出于西丘。 七玄飞节，九孔琼珠，云浆琳液，玄圃琅腴，钟山白胶，金生青敷，阆风石脑，黑河珊瑚，蒙山白泄，玉肺灵丘，苍鸾金津，东英朱瓜，九节交结，太微紫麻。 琼华玉实，流渊鲸波，赤河绛璧。 北汲太极之井，中缀文朱之脉。 云庭神桃，昆园玉液。 夜精日草，青津碧荻。 上招神光，下饮玄濑。 仰握玄圃之琼精，俯摘园丘之紫柰。 白水灵蛤，八天赤薤； 万载一生，流光九裔。 有得食之，太上之宝贵也。 又云：九石炼烟，丹液玉滋，荀首流珠，斑华石精，丹炉金液，紫华虹英，太清九转，五云之浆，玄霜绛雪，腾跃三黄，东瀛白香，沧浪青钱，高丘余粮，积石飞田，太虚还丹，太素玄坚，长光流草，云童飞千，亦能使人上飞轻举也。 又云：三十六芝，飞炉炼烟，阳水月华，五公之腴，镇生五藏，炼貌易躯，乃至瑰葩云屑，金粉玉柔，亦能延年至万岁也。 又云：玄水云华浆，五黄郁灵中，精干石□饭，众青朱英，白车飞节之实，流乌紫木之黄，一服立使人长算千纪也。
chunks.translated_text:
Should one emerge after forty years, twenty years, ten years, or three years—each according to their will—at the moment of rebirth, blood is gathered anew, flesh nurtured, fluids generated, and essence reconstituted into form, surpassing even their appearance before death. This is what is meant by "the Perfected refining the body in the Great Yin, transforming countenance in the Three Bureaus."

The Heavenly Thearch Lord states: "Refining the body in the Great Yin excels all; consuming the Nine-Turned Elixir, one’s form becomes upright and solemn, the complexion like numinous clouds. Ascending the Terrace of the Great Ultimate, one’s name is inscribed among the Perfected."

It further cites the Nine Radiance Serene Consort: "Worries and burdens do not disturb the Mystic Abode; sorrowful thoughts do not agitate the Crimson Ford. In tranquil detachment and distant contemplation, one delights in the shared reflection of light. Observing the four seasons in their revolutions, daily attaining perfection, one gazes into the farthest reaches, all having merged with the divine."

The days for audience at the Jade Court are: the fourth day of the first month, the fifteenth day of the third month, the eighth day of the fourth month, the fourth day of the sixth month, the seventh day of the seventh month, the eighth day of the eighth month, the ninth day of the ninth month, the fifth day of the tenth month, the third day of the eleventh month, and the twelfth day of the twelfth month.

The days for audience at the Great Simplicity are: the ninth day of the first month, the eighth day of the second month, the seventh day of the third month, the sixth day of the fourth month, the fifth day of the fifth month, the fourth day of the sixth month, the second day of the seventh month, the second day of the eighth month, the first day of the ninth month, the tenth day of the tenth month, the eleventh day of the eleventh month, and the twelfth day of the twelfth month.

The days for audience at the Great Ultimate are: the first day of the first month, the twentieth day of the second month, the twenty-seventh day of the third month, the sixth day of the sixth month, the twentieth day of the eighth month, the third day of the eleventh month, and the sixth day of the twelfth month.

On the seventh, eleventh, and fifteenth days of the month, one visualizes the Mystic Elixir.
On the first, eleventh, sixteenth, twenty-first, and twenty-sixth days of the month, one visualizes the Precious Mirror—envisioning one’s two eyes transformed into two luminous mirrors, illuminating the entire body.

On the first, fifteenth, and twenty-seventh days of the month, one consumes the Mingtang Talisman and the Imperial Likeness Talisman.
On *dingmao* days, one pays audience to the Azure Lad.
On *jian* and *chu* days, one visualizes the Three Ones.
At the *yin* hour, one visualizes the Three Sections of the Upper Radiance Talisman and consumes the Mystic Perfection.
On *mao* days, one consumes mist, the solar emblem, the solar rays, the Seven Stars Talisman, the Dissolution Talisman, pays audience to the Supreme Subtlety, audience to the Jade Dawn, and consumes the Three Qi and the Soaring Dragon.

At the *xu* hour, one consumes lunar essence, Mystic Perfection, and lunar rays.
At the *hai* hour, one absorbs water, recites the incantation of the Three Clouds, the Five Bamboo Shoots, the Six Palaces, visualizes the Great Lord, lies reciting the Sword and Ring, and further visualizes the Dipper, the Lower Radiance, and the Five of the Head.
At the *chen* and *chou* hours, one visualizes the Double Radiance—all these are methods for cultivating the Dao.

It further states: "Ascending the Mystic, pacing the flying steps, and returning in gratitude; restraining the *hun* and controlling the *po*—these too are its methods."

The *Upper Clarity Scripture on Dispelling Demons* says: "Jade teeth and dense blossoms, the Seven Yangs’ Infant, the fluid of the Nine Jades, the essence of the Eight Precious Stones, the purple nectar of the Four Pistils, the Five Pearls descending to give birth to the Three Florets flying as steel, the twin pearls of lunar brightness, orchid liquid and golden stalks, sweet dew in jade vases, divine lotus elixir and cinnabar powder, cloud branches linked in camps, jade groves forming at dawn, the Western Thearch’s plain abundance—rinsing and transforming these, one enters the Purple Court."

It further says: "The waters of the Eastern Culmen’s Weaving Maiden, the westernmost reaches of Long Geng and Yu Yuan, the southern extremity of the Yang Light’s root, the northern depths of the Great Yin’s Liquid Citadel."

It further says: "From the north, gather the black crabapple of the Mystic Expanse; gazing upward, rinse the vermilion honey of cloud mountains. From the east, pluck the cinnabar mulberries of Fusang; bending down, probe the patterned algae of the Long Abyss. Above, harmonize the flying jade of the Nine Turns; below, swallow the rosy treasures of the Azure Mystery. The Great Void forms its rings; the Plain Infant cradles them. The Purple Dragon Lad, the Nine-Enveloped Phoenix Brain, the Hidden Mushroom of the Great Ultimate, the Crimson Tree of the Solar Path, the Rainbow Plum of the Supreme, the Great Grass of the Celestial Han, the Giant Pearl of the Southern Palace, the Aged Supporter of the Western Ministers, the Three-Beamed Dragon Flower—these are what the Numinous Consort seeks. Those who obtain and consume them divide their spirit into myriad paths."

It further says: "The secluded mushrooms of the Upper Clarity, the Great Harmony; the speckled dragon’s black embryo, the striped tiger’s white foam—these emerge from the Western Mound. The Seven Mysteries’ flying nodes, the Nine Apertures’ jade pearls, cloud nectar and numinous fluid, the jade richness of the Mystic Orchard, the white glue of Bell Mountain, gold born of blue unfolding, the stone brain of Langfeng, the black river’s coral, the white discharge of Meng Mountain, the jade lungs of the Numinous Mound, the azure simurgh’s golden essence, the Eastern Flower’s vermilion melon, the nine-jointed interlacing, the purple hemp of the Supreme Subtlety. Jade blossoms and jade fruits, the whale waves of Flowing Abyss, the red river’s crimson jade. From the north, draw from the well of the Great Ultimate; in the center, string the vermilion veins of the Patterned Cinnabar. The divine peach of the Cloud Court, the jade fluid of Kun Garden. The night essence and solar grass, the azure ford and blue reeds. Above, summon the divine radiance; below, drink from the dark rapids. Gaze upward to grasp the jade essence of the Mystic Orchard; bend down to pluck the purple crabapple of the Garden Mound. chunks.original_text: 朱灵，丹液之鲜洁者。 五液夷泯，百关通盈，五藏之液平和调定而关节皆得宣溢，故无复淍枯之患。 又云：复励以晨漱华泉五方灵精，鸣鼓玉池，呼吸玄清，兼用云芽之法，漱濯清泉，以助充其润，则气质并康也。 华腴童於□方胃满镇乎空青者，蜜能变老还少，使目青色洁。 空青镇胤补液，故肠满□光。 又云：所以千算一启，寿随年荣，岁与药进，飞步仙庭，服尽一剂，命不复倾。 五云生身，体神气精者，青童云：长算千祀，谓一剂而已。 故言千算一启，服十剂则寿万年。 五方之老来降青精之人，神附体则成真人也。 太极真人青精干石□饭，上仙灵方也。 注云：此草有青精之神，而又杂朱青，以为干饭，故谓青干石□饭也。 □音迅。 此则诸宫上仙之灵方，非下法也。 豫章西山青米，吴越青龙稻米是也。 青米理虚而受药气。 南烛草木捣取汁，以淹青龙之米，作药服之。 其树是木，而似草，故号曰南烛草木也。 一名猴药，一名男续，一名后卓，一名惟那木，一名草木之王。 生嵩高少室、抱犊鸡头山，名山皆有，非但数处而已。 江左吴越至多。 其土人名之曰猴叔，或曰染叔，似栀子。 其子如菜英，《清虚真人王君内传》说其方法大具也。 《上元宝经》曰：子食草木之王气，与神通子食青烛之津，命不复陨也。 青精南烛，故兼云青烛也，服之仙矣。 又云：常漱玄池之华，以益六液也。 注云：勤修云芽之道，以充六府之气也。 空青者，虚曜而童面，上仙品石药及草木也。 荆木者，《六甲阴符》云一名羊栌，一名空疏，一名壮荆。 《上清六甲内经》有上清琼宫五帝内思上法，上清灵飞六甲内思通灵上法，清虚真人醮灵飞上法。 《八素经》云：日精赤以金精，石景水母之英，炼於日魂，曜精八芒，服之精元幽关，体生奇光，与日月同年。 月光黄华，常以月二十五日经於东井之上，沐浴灵晖，莹饰精芒，鲜明黄华也。 夫欲求仙，当以其日采黄华於东井，服阳精於月魂，润流九孔之内，神镇五府之宫，修行其道，上升月庭。 月魂在东井之内，则日月通晖之户。 《三元真一经》云：苏林服保灵松烟流青紫丸，令人长生，出阴入阳，颜色曰与玉同光。 又曰：真人涓子云：必欲服食者，当先去三尸。 三尸不去，虽断谷绝五味，虫犹不死，人体重滞，所梦非真，颠倒翻错。 邪欲不除，由於虫在其内，摇动五神故也。 又云：制仙丸者，太上八宜飞精之丹也。 又有制虫神丸也，又云琴高先生受镇气益命之道，又行补精反丹之法。 《宝剑上经》云：太极曲晨八景飞精，名之曰太极藏景录形灵丸，服之能浮景云霄，飞行太虚。 《三元玉检》云：九天真王乘九色之凤也。 《三道顺行经》云：南极上元君受高上顺行三道之要，黄气阳精之道，翕御灵晖，口歠皇华，仰餐飞根，存七曜於紫晨，三景垂映，七精翼轩，五灵交带，四司结篇，西龟定录，名题高晨也。 《登真隐诀第四》云：太极真人服四极云芽也。 《宝剑上经》云：胡仙芝草，飞天之华。 又有反生之香，玉蜜之山也。 《金根经》云：餐霞咽气，咀嚼玄根。 《大有上经》云：泥丸天帝三一者，乃一身之灵宗，百神之命根，津液之山源，魂精之玉室。 是以胃池体方以受物，脑宫圆虚而适真，万毛植立，千孔生烟，德备天地，混洞太玄，故名之曰泥丸。

The vermilion spirit is the pure and radiant essence of cinnabar liquid. When the five fluids harmonize and dissipate, the hundred passages become full and flowing, the fluids of the five viscera achieve balance and regulation, and all joints receive their proper overflow—thus, there is no longer the affliction of withering and desiccation.

It is also said: Reinforce this with morning rinses of the Flowering Spring’s five-directional numinous essences, sounding the drum of the Jade Pool, inhaling and exhaling the dark purity, and concurrently employing the method of cloud sprouts—rinsing and washing with clear springs to assist in replenishing their moisture. Then both qi and substance will be sound and flourishing.

The Flowery Richness, when steamed in the □ direction until the stomach is full and settled with malachite, transforms honey to reverse aging and restore youth, making the eyes bright and clear. Malachite stabilizes the generative essence and replenishes fluids, thus filling the intestines with □ radiance.

It is further said: Therefore, with a single initiation of a thousand calculations, longevity follows the flourishing of years. As the years advance with the medicine, one ascends the immortal courts in flying steps. After consuming one dose, life no longer declines. The Five Clouds generate the body, embodying the spirit, qi, and essence. The Azure Lad says: A thousand years of long calculation refers to a single dose. Thus, it is said that a thousand calculations begin with one initiation; consuming ten doses grants ten thousand years of life. When the elders of the five directions descend to bestow the Azure Essence upon a person, and the spirit attaches to the body, that person becomes a perfected one.

The Supreme Ultimate Perfected One’s Azure Essence Dried Stone □ Meal is a divine recipe of the highest immortals. The commentary states: This herb possesses the spirit of Azure Essence and is also mixed with vermilion and azure to make dried meals, hence it is called Azure Dried Stone □ Meal. □ is pronounced *xùn*. This is a divine recipe of the highest immortal palaces, not a lesser method.

The azure rice of Mount Yu-zhang’s Western Mountain and the Azure Dragon rice of Wu and Yue are examples. Azure rice regulates deficiency and receives the qi of medicines. Pound the Southern Candle herb and tree to extract their juice, then soak the Azure Dragon rice in it to prepare the medicine for consumption. This tree is woody yet resembles a herb, hence it is called the Southern Candle herb-tree. It is also named Monkey Medicine, Male Continuance, Posterior Excellence, Wei-na Wood, and King of Herbs and Trees. It grows on Mount Song’s Shao-shi, Mount Bao-du’s Chicken Head Mountain, and in all famous mountains—not merely in a few places. In the regions of Jiang-zuo and Wu-Yue, it is especially abundant. The locals call it Monkey Uncle or Dye Uncle, resembling gardenia. Its seeds resemble the fruit of the *Zanthoxylum* tree. The *Inner Transmission of Perfected King Jun of Pure Emptiness* elaborates on its methods in full.

The *Upper Prime Treasure Scripture* states: Those who consume the qi of the King of Herbs and Trees commune with the spirit; those who consume the sap of the Azure Candle will never fall. The Southern Candle is Azure Essence, hence it is also called Azure Candle. Consuming it leads to immortality.

It is also said: Regularly rinse with the Flower of the Dark Pool to benefit the six fluids. The commentary states: Diligently cultivate the Way of Cloud Sprouts to replenish the qi of the six palaces. Malachite is empty and luminous, with a youthful countenance—it is a superior immortal-grade mineral medicine as well as an herb or tree.

Regarding the thorn tree, the *Six Jia Yin Talismans* states it is also called Goat Thorn, Hollow Sparse, and Strong Thorn. The *Upper Clarity Six Jia Inner Scripture* contains the *Upper Clarity Jade Palace Five Thearchs’ Inner Contemplation Upper Method*, the *Upper Clarity Numinous Flight Six Jia Inner Contemplation Communion with the Numinous Upper Method*, and the *Pure Emptiness Perfected One’s Offering to the Numinous Flight Upper Method*.

The *Eight Simplicities Scripture* states: The sun’s essence is red with the metal’s essence; the stone’s radiance is the flower of the Water Mother. Refined by the sun’s soul, its eight rays shine. Consuming it, the mysterious gates of essence and spirit generate wondrous light in the body, granting the same lifespan as the sun and moon.

The Yellow Flower of Moonlight: On the twenty-fifth day of the lunar month, when the moon passes above the Eastern Well, bathe in its numinous radiance to adorn and refine the essence’s rays, making the Yellow Flower bright and resplendent. Those who seek immortality should gather the Yellow Flower from the Eastern Well on that day, consume the yang essence from the moon’s soul, allowing it to flow and moisten the nine orifices, and spiritually stabilize the five palaces’ chambers. Cultivating this Way, one ascends to the moon’s court. The moon’s soul resides within the Eastern Well, which is the gateway where the sun and moon’s radiance commune.

The *Three Primes True Unity Scripture* states: Su Lin consumed the Flowing Azure Purple Pellets of Preserving the Numinous Pine Smoke, granting longevity, emerging from yin into yang, and making one’s complexion shine like jade.

It is also said: Perfected One Juan-zi stated: Those who wish to consume medicines must first expel the Three Corpses. If the Three Corpses are not expelled, even if one abstains from grains and the five flavors, the worms will not die. The body will grow heavy, dreams will be unreal, and thoughts will be confused and inverted. Evil desires will not be eliminated because the worms reside within, agitating the five spirits.

It is further said: The Restraining Immortal Pellets are the Supreme Eight Proprieties’ Flying Essence Elixir. There are also the Worm-Restraining Divine Pellets. It is also said: Master Qin Gao received the Way of Stabilizing Qi and Benefiting Life, and practiced the method of Replenishing Essence and Returning the Elixir.

The *Upper Scripture of the Sacred Sword* states: The Supreme Ultimate’s Curved Dawn Eight Radiance Flying Essence is named the Supreme Ultimate Hidden Radiance Recorded Form Numinous Pellet. Consuming it enables one to float upon the clouds and soar through the Great Void.

The *Three Primes Jade Tallies* states: The Nine Heavens’ True King rides the nine-colored phoenix.

The *Scripture of the Three Ways’ Sequential Practice* states: The Upper Prime Lord of the Southern Culmen received the essentials of the Highest Sequential Practice of the Three Ways—the Way of Yellow Qi and Yang Essence. Gathering and guiding the numinous radiance, sipping the August Flower, gazing upward to consume the Flying Root, contemplating the Seven Luminaries in the Purple Dawn, the Three Radiance’s reflections hanging down, the Seven Essences flanking the chariot, the Five Numinous intertwining like sashes, the Four Offices composing the chapters, the Western Tortoise determining the records—this is titled the Inscription of the Lofty Dawn.

The *Fourth Hidden Instructions of Ascending Perfection* states: The Supreme Ultimate Perfected One consumed the Four Poles’ Cloud Sprouts.

The *Upper Scripture of the Sacred Sword* states: The Barbarian Immortal Mushroom is the flower of flying to heaven. There is also the Fragrance of Reversed Life and the Mountain of Jade Honey.

The *Golden Root Scripture* states: Consume the radiance and swallow the qi, chewing the mysterious root.

The *Upper Scripture of Great Possession* states: The Three Ones of the Mud-Pellet Heavenly Thearch are the numinous ancestors of the single body, the life roots of the hundred spirits, the mountain source of fluids and humors, and the jade chamber of the soul’s essence. Thus, the Stomach Pool’s body is square to receive things, the Brain Palace is round and empty to accommodate the true. Ten thousand hairs stand erect, a thousand pores emit smoke, virtue equips one with heaven and earth, and one merges with the Great Mystery—hence it is named the Mud-Pellet.

chunks.original_text: 泥丸者，体形之上神也。 又云：两眉间却入，左有明童真君，右有明女真官，中有明镜神君。 此三君，共治明堂宫，腰带四玉铃，口衔玉镜，铃并赤玉也。 若道士恐畏，存三神使鸣玉铃，使声闻太极，使吐镜，光令万丈，存见此三君，口吐赤气，使灌兆口，则千妖伏息，万鬼灭形。 若道士饥渴，吸而咽之，须臾吐赤气，使灌兆口，因吸而咽之，须臾自饱也。 又旦起皆咽液三十过，以手拭面摩目以为常，存唾变作津液也。 《太一帝君洞真玄经》云：欲存服日月之气者，当知日月景象，日圆形而方景，月方精而圆象，景藏形内，精隐象中，景赤象黄，是为日月之魂。 若知其道，乃可以吐纳流霞也。 服日气之法，以平旦采月华，以夜半存之，令光景，照我泥丸，下及五藏，洞彻一形，常得长生。 又云：存日入我口，如味也。 存月入我脐中，当命门下照阴室之间也。 又云：闭目啄齿五过，以左手第三指捻鼻下人中七过，以右手第二指捻两眉九过。 此为却辔三五七九封制百神门户之法也。 《玄母八门经》云：太素真人所服之药者，云草玄清者，黑苣藤腴也。 一名玄清也。 卉醴华英者，白蜜也。 五光七白灵蔬者，薤菜也。 白素飞龙者，白石英也。 黑苣藤腴，白蜜凝雪者。 又云：云腴者，味香甘美，强而补精，镇生五藏，守气凝液，长养魂魄，真上药。 又云：腴蜜，名曰玄水玉液，一名飞龙云腴，一名炼五石之华膏也。 至十五年，身有玉光，内外洞彻，长生天地，役使鬼神。 三年之后，眼见夜书也。 此药逾於八石之饵也。 又复五石入喉，宝炼五藏，五藏上皆生五色华也。 又云：常服日月之精华者，欲得常食竹笋。 竹笋者，日华之胎也。 一名太明。 又欲食松叶也。 松者，木之秀也。 欲服日月，当食此物气以感运也。 太虚真人曰：松者，木之秀也。 其松栢，皆曰秀木也。 《大洞经》云：道君散教养形，吐故受新，摄精逐秽，漱晨华以招日皇，挹夜明以抱月珠，结璘吸霄，双景合游，飞芝葩玄，灵若被岫。 又云：道君吐纳七冥，六度挥惠，八解寄成，略略远畅，飘飘绝冥，心泊节淡，以回孩婴也。 又云：道君仰簪日华，拾落月珠，摘绛林之琅实，饵玄河之紫蕖，偃赛灵轩，领理虎书。 又云：暧沫三黄，绛液易精，九琳吐芒，琅圩百变，碧映水阳，八琼飞景，萎蕤绿浆，曲晨乘霄，流金月明，玄津玉液，灵腴五公，光叶散音，一唱八张，波若火精，伊离玉姜，金鉴百会，舍利炼香，郁郁灵宝，化易文章。 刀圭既陈，寿不可量，皇真元之珍药，上帝之所秘也。 或炼五云玉华灵金饵，朱魄绿蕖，华腴碧精，南烛翠□，沉沙空青，朝采五晨，玉渊素浆，亦能反故还新，变老得婴也。 又云：悬五炼而水柔，九琳洞合而玉成。 火琅遂珠，流金采琼，有齐上契，命胡可倾。 《登真隐诀第四》云：太极真人服四极云芽神仙上方，揖五方元晨之晖，食九霞之精也。 注云：谓清晨之元气，始晖之霞精。 日阳数九，是曰九霞。 本文云：所以神光内曜，朱华外陈，体生玉瑛。 注云：形与明挹晨晖以止渴，食霞精以充根。 藏府与神光合曜，色貌随朱华共鲜。 玉润映体，和气明形，皆五晨之灵锋，六澧之渊液，所能致也。
